children.subject:
In the case that it's not offered, here is my advice (as someone who is taking CS 182 this semester). I think CS 182 is a good class, but I don't think it's so necessary for grad applications that you need to take a gap semester and delay a cycle for grad apps (assuming this is what you want to do). Even though there is a lot of hype around neural networks, I think grad schools are looking for your competence in ML more generally (including research, internships, SOP, projects, etc.), and you can definitely take an equivalent class later on in grad school.

In fact, most of the assignments in the course are taken from assignments of other available courses (like Stanford's 231n Assignments 2 & 3, and Berkeley's CS 294-112 homeworks on Policy Gradients and Q-Learning; the lectures for these courses are also available online), so if you're worried on missing out on some material compared to others who have taken the course, then you can definitely find them and do them at your own pace (which is what I think the webcasted version of the course is anyway). This is the link to the course website, if you want to look through it yourself.

Again, in the case that it's not offered I would look at the fall course catalog and pick the classes that most relate to your interests (for example anything out of CS 188/EE 126/EE 127 if you haven't taken those is probably good, or even CS 194-26 if you are interested in computer vision). Also Info 159 (NLP) is a good course, but I don't think it's offered in the fall. Since you've taken CS 189, you could also look into CS 285 (Deep Reinforcement Learning) or CS C281A (SLT), if you have the other prereqs.

For the design requirement there isn't really a good undergrad ML alternative to CS 182, and I'll leave it to someone else to recommend a solution for that. But ultimately I don't think the absence of one specific ML class will affect your grad school applications, and it's definitely not worth two years of your life (by delaying your graduation and grad school apps) to do it.

A gap semester is not worth for 182. The course is more like a survey of deep learning techniques used in CV, NLP, RL and other stuffs. Many online courses contain that. For design requirement, highly recommend 162, since I think for a CS major knowing process, thread, multithreading and distributed system seem like a must. If 162 seems to much work, at least take 186 lol.

history.content:
Fall will be my last semester at Cal. I still need my design requirement, and I planned to do 182 (w) for that requirement at least a year ago. I'm currently taking 189 and 182 seems like the best course for me to take next. However, it doesn't seem like 182 will be offered next fall, which is surprising considering its one of the few cs classes already done online. Given that the fall semester will be hybrid, and very likely remote again, what are the chances that 182 will be added?

If 182 isn't added, should I take a gap semester, take 182 in the spring, then graduate? Would that mess up grad school applications? I was originally planning to apply to programs in the fall.
history.subject: Chances of 182 being offered in Fall, given semester is hybrid
